text_entry: ACT I
SCENE I. London. The palace.
Enter KING HENRY, LORD JOHN OF LANCASTER, the EARL of WESTMORELAND, SIR WALTER BLUNT, and others
So shaken as we are, so wan with care,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Find we a time for frighted peace to pant,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And breathe short-winded accents of new broils
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To be commenced in strands afar remote.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: No more the thirsty entrance of this soil
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Shall daub her lips with her own children's blood;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Nor more shall trenching war channel her fields,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Nor bruise her flowerets with the armed hoofs
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of hostile paces: those opposed eyes,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Which, like the meteors of a troubled heaven,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: All of one nature, of one substance bred,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Did lately meet in the intestine shock
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And furious close of civil butchery
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Shall now, in mutual well-beseeming ranks,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: March all one way and be no more opposed
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Against acquaintance, kindred and allies:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: The edge of war, like an ill-sheathed knife,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: No more shall cut his master. Therefore, friends,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: As far as to the sepulchre of Christ,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Whose soldier now, under whose blessed cross
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: We are impressed and engaged to fight,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Forthwith a power of English shall we levy;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Whose arms were moulded in their mothers' womb
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To chase these pagans in those holy fields
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Over whose acres walk'd those blessed feet
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Which fourteen hundred years ago were nail'd
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: For our advantage on the bitter cross.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: But this our purpose now is twelve month old,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And bootless 'tis to tell you we will go:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Therefore we meet not now. Then let me hear
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of you, my gentle cousin Westmoreland,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: What yesternight our council did decree
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: In forwarding this dear expedience.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: My liege, this haste was hot in question,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: And many limits of the charge set down
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: But yesternight: when all athwart there came
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: A post from Wales loaden with heavy news;
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Whose worst was, that the noble Mortimer,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Leading the men of Herefordshire to fight
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Against the irregular and wild Glendower,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Was by the rude hands of that Welshman taken,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: A thousand of his people butchered;
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Upon whose dead corpse there was such misuse,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Such beastly shameless transformation,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: By those Welshwomen done as may not be
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Without much shame retold or spoken of.
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: It seems then that the tidings of this broil
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Brake off our business for the Holy Land.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: This match'd with other did, my gracious lord;
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: For more uneven and unwelcome news
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Came from the north and thus it did import:
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: On Holy-rood day, the gallant Hotspur there,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Young Harry Percy and brave Archibald,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: That ever-valiant and approved Scot,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: At Holmedon met,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Where they did spend a sad and bloody hour,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: As by discharge of their artillery,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: And shape of likelihood, the news was told;
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: For he that brought them, in the very heat
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: And pride of their contention did take horse,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Uncertain of the issue any way.
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Here is a dear, a true industrious friend,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Sir Walter Blunt, new lighted from his horse.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Stain'd with the variation of each soil
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Betwixt that Holmedon and this seat of ours;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And he hath brought us smooth and welcome news.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: The Earl of Douglas is discomfited:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Ten thousand bold Scots, two and twenty knights,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Balk'd in their own blood did Sir Walter see
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: On Holmedon's plains. Of prisoners, Hotspur took
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Mordake the Earl of Fife, and eldest son
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To beaten Douglas; and the Earl of Athol,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of Murray, Angus, and Menteith:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And is not this an honourable spoil?
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: A gallant prize? ha, cousin, is it not?
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: In faith,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: It is a conquest for a prince to boast of.
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Yea, there thou makest me sad and makest me sin
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: In envy that my Lord Northumberland
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Should be the father to so blest a son,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: A son who is the theme of honour's tongue;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Amongst a grove, the very straightest plant;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Who is sweet Fortune's minion and her pride:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Whilst I, by looking on the praise of him,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: See riot and dishonour stain the brow
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of my young Harry. O that it could be proved
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: That some night-tripping fairy had exchanged
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: In cradle-clothes our children where they lay,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And call'd mine Percy, his Plantagenet!
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Then would I have his Harry, and he mine.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: But let him from my thoughts. What think you, coz,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of this young Percy's pride? the prisoners,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Which he in this adventure hath surprised,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To his own use he keeps; and sends me word,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: I shall have none but Mordake Earl of Fife.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: This is his uncle's teaching; this is Worcester,
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Malevolent to you in all aspects;
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Which makes him prune himself, and bristle up
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: The crest of youth against your dignity.
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: But I have sent for him to answer this;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And for this cause awhile we must neglect
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Our holy purpose to Jerusalem.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Cousin, on Wednesday next our council we
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Will hold at Windsor; so inform the lords:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: But come yourself with speed to us again;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: For more is to be said and to be done
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Than out of anger can be uttered.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: I will, my liege.
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Exeunt
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: SCENE II. London. An apartment of the Prince's.
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Enter the PRINCE OF WALES and FALSTAFF
speaker: WESTMORELAND

text_entry: Now, Hal, what time of day is it, lad?
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: Thou art so fat-witted, with drinking of old sack
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: and unbuttoning thee after supper and sleeping upon
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: benches after noon, that thou hast forgotten to
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: demand that truly which thou wouldst truly know.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: What a devil hast thou to do with the time of the
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: day? Unless hours were cups of sack and minutes
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: capons and clocks the tongues of bawds and dials the
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: signs of leaping-houses and the blessed sun himself
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: a fair hot wench in flame-coloured taffeta, I see no
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: reason why thou shouldst be so superfluous to demand
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: the time of the day.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Indeed, you come near me now, Hal; for we that take
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: purses go by the moon and the seven stars, and not
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: by Phoebus, he,'that wandering knight so fair.' And,
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: I prithee, sweet wag, when thou art king, as, God
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: save thy grace,--majesty I should say, for grace
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: thou wilt have none,--
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: What, none?
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: No, by my troth, not so much as will serve to
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: prologue to an egg and butter.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: Well, how then? come, roundly, roundly.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Marry, then, sweet wag, when thou art king, let not
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: us that are squires of the night's body be called
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: thieves of the day's beauty: let us be Diana's
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: foresters, gentlemen of the shade, minions of the
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: moon; and let men say we be men of good government,
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: being governed, as the sea is, by our noble and
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: chaste mistress the moon, under whose countenance we steal.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: Thou sayest well, and it holds well too; for the
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: fortune of us that are the moon's men doth ebb and
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: flow like the sea, being governed, as the sea is,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: by the moon. As, for proof, now: a purse of gold
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: most resolutely snatched on Monday night and most
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: dissolutely spent on Tuesday morning; got with
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: swearing 'Lay by' and spent with crying 'Bring in;'
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: now in as low an ebb as the foot of the ladder
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: and by and by in as high a flow as the ridge of the gallows.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: By the Lord, thou sayest true, lad. And is not my
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: hostess of the tavern a most sweet wench?
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: As the honey of Hybla, my old lad of the castle. And
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: is not a buff jerkin a most sweet robe of durance?
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: How now, how now, mad wag! what, in thy quips and
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: thy quiddities? what a plague have I to do with a
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: buff jerkin?
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: Why, what a pox have I to do with my hostess of the tavern?
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Well, thou hast called her to a reckoning many a
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: time and oft.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: Did I ever call for thee to pay thy part?
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: No; I'll give thee thy due, thou hast paid all there.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: Yea, and elsewhere, so far as my coin would stretch;
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: and where it would not, I have used my credit.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Yea, and so used it that were it not here apparent
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: that thou art heir apparent--But, I prithee, sweet
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: wag, shall there be gallows standing in England when
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: thou art king? and resolution thus fobbed as it is
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: with the rusty curb of old father antic the law? Do
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: not thou, when thou art king, hang a thief.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: No; thou shalt.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Shall I? O rare! By the Lord, I'll be a brave judge.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: Thou judgest false already: I mean, thou shalt have
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: the hanging of the thieves and so become a rare hangman.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Well, Hal, well; and in some sort it jumps with my
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: humour as well as waiting in the court, I can tell
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: you.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: For obtaining of suits?
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Yea, for obtaining of suits, whereof the hangman
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: hath no lean wardrobe. 'Sblood, I am as melancholy
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: as a gib cat or a lugged bear.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: Or an old lion, or a lover's lute.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Yea, or the drone of a Lincolnshire bagpipe.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: What sayest thou to a hare, or the melancholy of
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Moor-ditch?
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: the most comparative, rascalliest, sweet young
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: prince. But, Hal, I prithee, trouble me no more
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: with vanity. I would to God thou and I knew where a
speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: yet he talked wisely, and in the street too.
speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: streets, and no man regards it.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: O, thou hast damnable iteration and art indeed able
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: to corrupt a saint. Thou hast done much harm upon
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: me, Hal; God forgive thee for it! Before I knew
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: thee, Hal, I knew nothing; and now am I, if a man
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: should speak truly, little better than one of the
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: wicked. I must give over this life, and I will give
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: it over: by the Lord, and I do not, I am a villain:

speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: PRINCE HENRY

speaker: PRINCE HENRY

speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: And so they shall.
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: The king will always think him in our debt,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: And think we think ourselves unsatisfied,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Till he hath found a time to pay us home:
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: And see already how he doth begin
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Cousin, farewell: no further go in this
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: When time is ripe, which will be suddenly,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: I'll steal to Glendower and Lord Mortimer;
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Where you and Douglas and our powers at once,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: As I will fashion it, shall happily meet,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: To bear our fortunes in our own strong arms,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Which now we hold at much uncertainty.
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Farewell, good brother: we shall thrive, I trust.
speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND

text_entry: Uncle, Adieu: O, let the hours be short
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Till fields and blows and groans applaud our sport!
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Exeunt
speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: LADY PERCY

speaker: LADY PERCY

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Than Harry Percy's wife: constant you are,
speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: No lady closer; for I well believe
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Thou wilt not utter what thou dost not know;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: And so far will I trust thee, gentle Kate.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: How! so far?
speaker: LADY PERCY

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: LADY PERCY

speaker: GLENDOWER

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Cousin, of many men

speaker: GLENDOWER

speaker: GLENDOWER

text_entry: These signs have mark'd me extraordinary;

text_entry: And all the courses of my life do show
speaker: GLENDOWER

speaker: GLENDOWER

speaker: GLENDOWER

text_entry: And bring him out that is but woman's son

speaker: GLENDOWER

text_entry: And hold me pace in deep experiments.

text_entry: Of all the court and princes of my blood:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: The hope and expectation of thy time
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Is ruin'd, and the soul of every man
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Prophetically doth forethink thy fall.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Had I so lavish of my presence been,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: So common-hackney'd in the eyes of men,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: So stale and cheap to vulgar company,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Opinion, that did help me to the crown,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Had still kept loyal to possession
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And left me in reputeless banishment,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: A fellow of no mark nor likelihood.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: By being seldom seen, I could not stir
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: But like a comet I was wonder'd at;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: That men would tell their children 'This is he;'
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Others would say 'Where, which is Bolingbroke?'
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And then I stole all courtesy from heaven,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And dress'd myself in such humility
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: That I did pluck allegiance from men's hearts,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Loud shouts and salutations from their mouths,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Even in the presence of the crowned king.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Thus did I keep my person fresh and new;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: My presence, like a robe pontifical,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Ne'er seen but wonder'd at: and so my state,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Seldom but sumptuous, showed like a feast
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And won by rareness such solemnity.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: The skipping king, he ambled up and down
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: With shallow jesters and rash bavin wits,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Soon kindled and soon burnt; carded his state,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Mingled his royalty with capering fools,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Had his great name profaned with their scorns
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And gave his countenance, against his name,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To laugh at gibing boys and stand the push
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of every beardless vain comparative,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Grew a companion to the common streets,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Enfeoff'd himself to popularity;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: That, being daily swallow'd by men's eyes,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: They surfeited with honey and began
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To loathe the taste of sweetness, whereof a little
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: More than a little is by much too much.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: So when he had occasion to be seen,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: He was but as the cuckoo is in June,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Heard, not regarded; seen, but with such eyes
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: As, sick and blunted with community,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Afford no extraordinary gaze,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Such as is bent on sun-like majesty
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: When it shines seldom in admiring eyes;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: But rather drowzed and hung their eyelids down,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Slept in his face and render'd such aspect
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: As cloudy men use to their adversaries,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Being with his presence glutted, gorged and full.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And in that very line, Harry, standest thou;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: For thou has lost thy princely privilege
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: With vile participation: not an eye
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: But is a-weary of thy common sight,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Save mine, which hath desired to see thee more;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Which now doth that I would not have it do,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Make blind itself with foolish tenderness.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: I shall hereafter, my thrice gracious lord,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Be more myself.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: For all the world
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: As thou art to this hour was Richard then
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: When I from France set foot at Ravenspurgh,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And even as I was then is Percy now.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Now, by my sceptre and my soul to boot,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: He hath more worthy interest to the state
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Than thou the shadow of succession;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: For of no right, nor colour like to right,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: He doth fill fields with harness in the realm,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Turns head against the lion's armed jaws,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And, being no more in debt to years than thou,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Leads ancient lords and reverend bishops on
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To bloody battles and to bruising arms.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: What never-dying honour hath he got
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Against renowned Douglas! whose high deeds,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Whose hot incursions and great name in arms
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Holds from all soldiers chief majority
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And military title capital
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Through all the kingdoms that acknowledge Christ:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Thrice hath this Hotspur, Mars in swathling clothes,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: This infant warrior, in his enterprises
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Discomfited great Douglas, ta'en him once,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Enlarged him and made a friend of him,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To fill the mouth of deep defiance up
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And shake the peace and safety of our throne.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And what say you to this? Percy, Northumberland,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: The Archbishop's grace of York, Douglas, Mortimer,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Capitulate against us and are up.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: But wherefore do I tell these news to thee?
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Why, Harry, do I tell thee of my foes,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Which art my near'st and dearest enemy?
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Thou that art like enough, through vassal fear,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Base inclination and the start of spleen
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To fight against me under Percy's pay,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To dog his heels and curtsy at his frowns,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To show how much thou art degenerate.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Do not think so; you shall not find it so:
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And God forgive them that so much have sway'd
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Your majesty's good thoughts away from me!
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: I will redeem all this on Percy's head
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And in the closing of some glorious day
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Be bold to tell you that I am your son;
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: When I will wear a garment all of blood
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And stain my favours in a bloody mask,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Which, wash'd away, shall scour my shame with it:
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And that shall be the day, whene'er it lights,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: That this same child of honour and renown,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: This gallant Hotspur, this all-praised knight,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And your unthought-of Harry chance to meet.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: For every honour sitting on his helm,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Would they were multitudes, and on my head
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: My shames redoubled! for the time will come,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: That I shall make this northern youth exchange
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: His glorious deeds for my indignities.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Percy is but my factor, good my lord,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: To engross up glorious deeds on my behalf;
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And I will call him to so strict account,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: That he shall render every glory up,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Yea, even the slightest worship of his time,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Or I will tear the reckoning from his heart.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: This, in the name of God, I promise here:
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: The which if He be pleased I shall perform,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: I do beseech your majesty may salve
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: The long-grown wounds of my intemperance:
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: If not, the end of life cancels all bands;
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And I will die a hundred thousand deaths
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Ere break the smallest parcel of this vow.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: A hundred thousand rebels die in this:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Thou shalt have charge and sovereign trust herein.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

speaker: KING HENRY IV

speaker: KING HENRY IV

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: The eleventh of this month at Shrewsbury
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: If promises be kept on every hand,
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: As ever offer'd foul play in the state.
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: The Earl of Westmoreland set forth to-day;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: With him my son, Lord John of Lancaster;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: For this advertisement is five days old:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: On Wednesday next, Harry, you shall set forward;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: On Thursday we ourselves will march: our meeting
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Is Bridgenorth: and, Harry, you shall march
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Through Gloucestershire; by which account,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Our business valued, some twelve days hence
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Our general forces at Bridgenorth shall meet.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Our hands are full of business: let's away;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Advantage feeds him fat, while men delay.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Exeunt
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of my cousin Vernon's are not yet come up:

text_entry: Your uncle Worcester's horse came but today;
speaker: VERNON

text_entry: And now their pride and mettle is asleep,
speaker: VERNON

text_entry: Their courage with hard labour tame and dull,
speaker: VERNON

text_entry: That not a horse is half the half of himself.
speaker: VERNON

text_entry: So are the horses of the enemy
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: In general, journey-bated and brought low:
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: The better part of ours are full of rest.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: The number of the king exceedeth ours:
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: For God's sake. cousin, stay till all come in.
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: The trumpet sounds a parley
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Enter SIR WALTER BLUNT
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: I come with gracious offers from the king,
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: if you vouchsafe me hearing and respect.
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Welcome, Sir Walter Blunt; and would to God
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: You were of our determination!
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Some of us love you well; and even those some
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Envy your great deservings and good name,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Because you are not of our quality,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: But stand against us like an enemy.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: And God defend but still I should stand so,
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: So long as out of limit and true rule
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: You stand against anointed majesty.
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: But to my charge. The king hath sent to know
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: The nature of your griefs, and whereupon
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: You conjure from the breast of civil peace
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Such bold hostility, teaching his duteous land
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Audacious cruelty. If that the king
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Have any way your good deserts forgot,
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Which he confesseth to be manifold,
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: He bids you name your griefs; and with all speed
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: You shall have your desires with interest
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: And pardon absolute for yourself and these
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Herein misled by your suggestion.
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: The king is kind; and well we know the king
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Knows at what time to promise, when to pay.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: My father and my uncle and myself
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Did give him that same royalty he wears;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: And when he was not six and twenty strong,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Sick in the world's regard, wretched and low,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: A poor unminded outlaw sneaking home,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: My father gave him welcome to the shore;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: And when he heard him swear and vow to God
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: He came but to be Duke of Lancaster,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: To sue his livery and beg his peace,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: With tears of innocency and terms of zeal,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: My father, in kind heart and pity moved,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Swore him assistance and perform'd it too.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Now when the lords and barons of the realm
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Perceived Northumberland did lean to him,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: The more and less came in with cap and knee;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Met him in boroughs, cities, villages,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Attended him on bridges, stood in lanes,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Laid gifts before him, proffer'd him their oaths,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Gave him their heirs, as pages follow'd him
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Even at the heels in golden multitudes.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: He presently, as greatness knows itself,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Steps me a little higher than his vow
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Made to my father, while his blood was poor,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Upon the naked shore at Ravenspurgh;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: And now, forsooth, takes on him to reform
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Some certain edicts and some strait decrees
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: That lie too heavy on the commonwealth,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Cries out upon abuses, seems to weep
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Over his country's wrongs; and by this face,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: This seeming brow of justice, did he win
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: The hearts of all that he did angle for;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Proceeded further; cut me off the heads
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Of all the favourites that the absent king
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: In deputation left behind him here,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: When he was personal in the Irish war.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Tut, I came not to hear this.
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Then to the point.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: In short time after, he deposed the king;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Soon after that, deprived him of his life;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: And in the neck of that, task'd the whole state:
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: To make that worse, suffer'd his kinsman March,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Who is, if every owner were well placed,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Indeed his king, to be engaged in Wales,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: There without ransom to lie forfeited;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Disgraced me in my happy victories,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Sought to entrap me by intelligence;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Rated mine uncle from the council-board;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: In rage dismiss'd my father from the court;
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Broke oath on oath, committed wrong on wrong,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: And in conclusion drove us to seek out
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: This head of safety; and withal to pry
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Into his title, the which we find
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Too indirect for long continuance.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Shall I return this answer to the king?
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Not so, Sir Walter: we'll withdraw awhile.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Go to the king; and let there be impawn'd
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Some surety for a safe return again,
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: And in the morning early shall my uncle
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Bring him our purposes: and so farewell.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: I would you would accept of grace and love.
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: And may be so we shall.
speaker: HOTSPUR

text_entry: Pray God you do.
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Exeunt
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: SCENE IV. York. The ARCHBISHOP'S palace.
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Enter the ARCHBISHOP OF YORK and SIR MICHAEL
speaker: SIR WALTER BLUNT

text_entry: Hie, good Sir Michael; bear this sealed brief
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: With winged haste to the lord marshal;
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: This to my cousin Scroop, and all the rest
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: To whom they are directed. If you knew
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: How much they do to import, you would make haste.
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: My good lord,
speaker: SIR MICHAEL

text_entry: I guess their tenor.
speaker: SIR MICHAEL

text_entry: Like enough you do.
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: To-morrow, good Sir Michael, is a day
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Wherein the fortune of ten thousand men
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Must bide the touch; for, sir, at Shrewsbury,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: As I am truly given to understand,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: The king with mighty and quick-raised power
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Meets with Lord Harry: and, I fear, Sir Michael,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: What with the sickness of Northumberland,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Whose power was in the first proportion,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: And what with Owen Glendower's absence thence,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Who with them was a rated sinew too
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: And comes not in, o'er-ruled by prophecies,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: I fear the power of Percy is too weak
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: To wage an instant trial with the king.
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Why, my good lord, you need not fear;
speaker: SIR MICHAEL

text_entry: There is Douglas and Lord Mortimer.
speaker: SIR MICHAEL

text_entry: No, Mortimer is not there.
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: But there is Mordake, Vernon, Lord Harry Percy,
speaker: SIR MICHAEL

text_entry: And there is my Lord of Worcester and a head
speaker: SIR MICHAEL

text_entry: Of gallant warriors, noble gentlemen.
speaker: SIR MICHAEL

text_entry: And so there is: but yet the king hath drawn
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: The special head of all the land together:
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: The Prince of Wales, Lord John of Lancaster,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: The noble Westmoreland and warlike Blunt;
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: And moe corrivals and dear men
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Of estimation and command in arms.
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Doubt not, my lord, they shall be well opposed.
speaker: SIR MICHAEL

text_entry: I hope no less, yet needful 'tis to fear;
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: And, to prevent the worst, Sir Michael, speed:
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: For if Lord Percy thrive not, ere the king
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Dismiss his power, he means to visit us,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: For he hath heard of our confederacy,
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: And 'tis but wisdom to make strong against him:
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Therefore make haste. I must go write again
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: To other friends; and so farewell, Sir Michael.
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: Exeunt
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: ACT V
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: SCENE I. KING HENRY IV's camp near Shrewsbury.
speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

speaker: ARCHBISHOP OF YORK

text_entry: How bloodily the sun begins to peer

text_entry: Above yon busky hill! the day looks pale
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: At his distemperature.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: The southern wind
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Doth play the trumpet to his purposes,

text_entry: And by his hollow whistling in the leaves

text_entry: Foretells a tempest and a blustering day.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Then with the losers let it sympathize,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: The trumpet sounds
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Enter WORCESTER and VERNON
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: How now, my Lord of Worcester! 'tis not well
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: That you and I should meet upon such terms
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: As now we meet. You have deceived our trust,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And made us doff our easy robes of peace,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To crush our old limbs in ungentle steel:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: This is not well, my lord, this is not well.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: What say you to it? will you again unknit
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: This curlish knot of all-abhorred war?
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And move in that obedient orb again
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Where you did give a fair and natural light,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And be no more an exhaled meteor,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: A prodigy of fear and a portent
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of broached mischief to the unborn times?
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Hear me, my liege:
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: For mine own part, I could be well content
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: To entertain the lag-end of my life
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: With quiet hours; for I do protest,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: I have not sought the day of this dislike.
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: You have not sought it! how comes it, then?
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Rebellion lay in his way, and he found it.
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: Peace, chewet, peace!
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: It pleased your majesty to turn your looks
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Of favour from myself and all our house;
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: And yet I must remember you, my lord,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: We were the first and dearest of your friends.
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: For you my staff of office did I break
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: In Richard's time; and posted day and night
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: to meet you on the way, and kiss your hand,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: When yet you were in place and in account
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Nothing so strong and fortunate as I.
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: It was myself, my brother and his son,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: That brought you home and boldly did outdare
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: The dangers of the time. You swore to us,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: And you did swear that oath at Doncaster,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: That you did nothing purpose 'gainst the state;
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Nor claim no further than your new-fall'n right,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: The seat of Gaunt, dukedom of Lancaster:
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: To this we swore our aid. But in short space
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: It rain'd down fortune showering on your head;
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: And such a flood of greatness fell on you,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: What with our help, what with the absent king,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: What with the injuries of a wanton time,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: The seeming sufferances that you had borne,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: And the contrarious winds that held the king
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: So long in his unlucky Irish wars
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: That all in England did repute him dead:
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: And from this swarm of fair advantages
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: You took occasion to be quickly woo'd
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: To gripe the general sway into your hand;
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Forget your oath to us at Doncaster;
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: And being fed by us you used us so
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: As that ungentle hull, the cuckoo's bird,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Useth the sparrow; did oppress our nest;
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Grew by our feeding to so great a bulk
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: That even our love durst not come near your sight
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: For fear of swallowing; but with nimble wing
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: We were enforced, for safety sake, to fly
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Out of sight and raise this present head;
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Whereby we stand opposed by such means
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: As you yourself have forged against yourself
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: By unkind usage, dangerous countenance,
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: And violation of all faith and troth
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: Sworn to us in your younger enterprise.
speaker: EARL OF WORCESTER

text_entry: These things indeed you have articulate,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Proclaim'd at market-crosses, read in churches,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: To face the garment of rebellion
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: With some fine colour that may please the eye
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of fickle changelings and poor discontents,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Which gape and rub the elbow at the news
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of hurlyburly innovation:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And never yet did insurrection want
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Such water-colours to impaint his cause;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Nor moody beggars, starving for a time
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Of pellmell havoc and confusion.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: In both your armies there is many a soul
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Shall pay full dearly for this encounter,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: If once they join in trial. Tell your nephew,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: The Prince of Wales doth join with all the world
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: In praise of Henry Percy: by my hopes,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: This present enterprise set off his head,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: I do not think a braver gentleman,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: More active-valiant or more valiant-young,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: More daring or more bold, is now alive
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: To grace this latter age with noble deeds.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: For my part, I may speak it to my shame,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: I have a truant been to chivalry;
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And so I hear he doth account me too;
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Yet this before my father's majesty--
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: I am content that he shall take the odds
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Of his great name and estimation,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And will, to save the blood on either side,
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: Try fortune with him in a single fight.
speaker: PRINCE HENRY

text_entry: And, Prince of Wales, so dare we venture thee,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Albeit considerations infinite
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Do make against it. No, good Worcester, no,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: We love our people well; even those we love
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: That are misled upon your cousin's part;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And, will they take the offer of our grace,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Both he and they and you, every man
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Shall be my friend again and I'll be his:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: So tell your cousin, and bring me word
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: What he will do: but if he will not yield,
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: Rebuke and dread correction wait on us
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: And they shall do their office. So, be gone;
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: We will not now be troubled with reply:
speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: We offer fair; take it advisedly.
speaker: KING HENRY IV

speaker: KING HENRY IV

text_entry: It will not be accepted, on my life:

speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: is that honour? air. A trim reckoning! Who hath it?
speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: he that died o' Wednesday. Doth he feel it? no.
speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF

text_entry: to the dead. But will it not live with the living?
speaker: FALSTAFF

speaker: FALSTAFF
